docs.lead_paragraph: After years of resistance, health maintenance organizations have agreed to help pay the costs of care for members who enroll in clinical trials evaluating new drugs and medical procedures. As a result, thousands of patients could receive promising new treatments they were denied in the past.

headline.main: Managed-Care Plans Agree to Help Pay the Costs of Their Members in Clinical Trials

docs.abstract: Health Maintenance organizations, after years of resistance, agree to help pay costs of care for members who enroll in clinical trials evaluating new drugs and medical procedures; agreement was negotiated over past year by National Institutes of Health and American Assn of Health Plans; terms noted (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: John Kovarik got a rude shock one day last year when he went to his pharmacy to fill a prescription: His insurance company refused to pay for it. ''I was flabbergasted,'' said Mr. Kovarik, a lawyer in South Palm Beach, Fla., with a life-threatening genetic disorder known as Wilson's disease. To fight its symptoms, Mr. Kovarik needs an effective treatment to keep copper from accumulating in his body and destroying his vital organs.

headline.main: Drug or Food? Patients Stumble Into Gray Area

docs.abstract: Some patients are finding that their insurance companies refuse to pay for a prescription drug because drug is also available over the counter as a food supplement; supplement and drug are supposed to be the same, but supplement is not licensed by Food and Drug Administration, so its manufacture is not regulated and there is no guarantee that dose on package is correct; crucial issue is patient safety; a product can be a drug if company tests it for safety and efficacy, receives approval from FDA and makes product according to Federal standards; but under current rules, many of same products can be sold as supplements if they do not make drug claims; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Whatever it is you may seek -- a memory boost, weight loss, stress relief, immune enhancement, mood elevation, sexual stimulation or therapy for your ailing heart, there is an herb being sold as the ''natural drug-free'' answer to your prayers. But experts warn that an ill-informed foray into the ever-expanding world of botanical medicines can end up causing more problems than it solves. Herbal products -- which are sold as dietary supplements, not drugs -- are virtually unregulated, leaving the fox (in this case, the manufacturer) to guard the hen house. While many companies are conscientious about providing high-quality products free of dangerous contaminants and containing what the label lists -- no more, no less -- others market cheaply made products that contain little or none of the stated ingredient or, worse, too much. One study of 64 ''pure'' ginseng products found that 60 percent of them were so watered down with cheaper herbs as to be worthless.

headline.main: 'Natural, Drug-Free' Herb May Have Risks of Its Own

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on wide variety of herbs being sold as 'natural drug-free' answer to myriad ailments; notes experts warn that an ill-informed foray into ever-expanding world of botanical medicines can end up causing more problems than it solves; notes herbal products--which are sold as dietary supplements, not drugs--are virtually unregulated, leaving the fox (the manufacturer) to guard the hen house; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Joan Carroll, a retired schoolteacher in Arlington, Tex., says she had to wait more than three months last year before she could be treated for acute stomach pain and dangerously high blood sugar levels. The reason? The medical specialists she needed would not take her as a patient because, she said, they were embroiled in a business dispute with her insurer, Aetna U.S. Healthcare.

headline.main: Insurers Moving to Limit Doctors' Contract Choices

docs.abstract: Insurance companies across nation are increasingly pressuring doctors who participate in any of their health plans into 'all-or-nothing' contracts that force them to participate in all of their plans, regardless of arrangements and payments for doctors; Aetna US Healthcare dispute with Tarrant County, Tex, doctors that forced subscribers to wait months to be seen by specialists cited; photo (M)
